title: angular Bauhaus-inspired "Summit" font
content:
I'm trying to locate yet another face for a customer. Any clues? I though I recognized it from a Bauhaus-inspired collection, but it escapes me at the moment. The closest similar I've found so far is Font Bureau's [Shimano Square Black Narrow](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518124719/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontbureau/shimano/squareblacknarrow/testdrive.html?s=SUMMIT&p=60), but I need something more serify.   
   
 ![Summit](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518124719im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/34451.gif)   
   
Thanks gang.
author: grant

comments.content: Grant are you setting alot of text with this? With its angles, if its just a couple of words, a talent like you could bang this out in no time.

Oh, it's not for me... it's for a Veer customer wanting to purchase some similar. I don't have any details regarding its usage, I just do IDs for our customer service crew when they get stumped.   
   
However, that's a good idea you had. If the customer isn't needing much more in terms of additional characters, it would be a breeze to whip up.

I would have called it Art Deco. BTW, when flipping through the Jaspert book for another post, I saw an inclined Roman called "Lunda" that has a lot in common with this sample. It was designed in 1941 by K. E. Forsberg, who designed Berling.

Thanks Mike.   
   
I wish I had more background information on the sample. I am going to guess that it was custom drawn, based on either some historical reference like you mentioned or perhaps because the designer had a ruler handy.
